team.wt.quinemccluskey

Class QuineMcCluskey

  • java.lang.Object
    • team.wt.quinemccluskey.QuineMcCluskey

  • public class QuineMcCluskey
extends java.lang.Object
    This program minimizes boolean function using Quine-McCluskey algorithm. This includes a GUI for the user to input the minterms and to show the solution as well as the minimized boolean function.
    Author:
    Lorenz Timothy Barco Ranera and Waleed Cruz Occidental

      • solveQMC

        public static void solveQMC(java.lang.String input)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Implements the Quine-McCluskey algorithm to minimize boolean function.
        Parameters:
        input - list of variables and minterms entered by the user
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - when the input is invalid

      • findBooleanFunction

        public static java.lang.String findBooleanFunction()
        Constructs the boolean function.
        Returns:
        the minimized boolean function

      • simplify

        public static java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> simplify(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> nEP,
                                                             java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> varNotInEP)
        Simplifies the list of implicants by removing those implicants whose variables are already included on other implicants
        Parameters:
        nEP - Prime Implicants that are not Essential
        varNotInEP - Minterms that are not in the Essential Prime Implicants
        Returns:
        a simplified Essential Prime Implicants which doesn't contain redundant prime implicants. For example (6,7),(11,15),(7,15) and the Minterms are 7,15. (6,7) and (7,15) will be removed because they are like the subset of (7,15).

      • combination

        public static void combination(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> nep,
                               java.lang.String[] item,
                               int start,
                               int end,
                               int index,
                               int r)
        Mimic's the principle of Petrick's method. It creates a list of combination of the remaining prime Implicants form choose 1 to choose k and it stops if a combination that satisfies all columns is generated.
        Parameters:
        nep - Prime Implicants that are not essential
        item - this stores a particular combination
        start - the start index of item
        end - the end index of item
        index - the index of item
        r - number of objects to be taken from a population

      • check

        public static java.lang.Boolean check(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> pEP,
                                      java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> varNotInEP)
        It checks if a certain combination can fulfill the remaining minterms
        Parameters:
        pEP - the possible essential prime implicants
        varNotInEP - Minterms that are not the essential prime implicants
        Returns:
        true if success
